item.title: Problem Solving – Thinking Clearly Under Interview Constraints
item.description:
Introduction to Problem Solving

1. Why This Section Exists

Most coding interviews do not test whether you can recall algorithms or data structures from memory.

They test whether you can:

  • understand an unfamiliar problem,
  • reason about constraints,
  • choose an appropriate approach,
  • and write correct, explainable code under time pressure.

This section exists to train that exact skill — the ability to think clearly when the solution is not immediately obvious.

item.title: How to Approach a Problem – A Universal Framework
item.description:
How to Approach a Problem – A Universal Framework

1. Why a Framework Matters

In interviews, most candidates fail not because the problem is too hard, but because they panic, jump to code, or reason inconsistently.

A framework gives you:

  • structure under pressure,
  • a way to make progress even when unsure,
  • and something intelligent to say at every stage.

This article introduces a universal problem-solving framework that applies to:

  • easy, medium, and hard problems,
  • CoderPad and whiteboard rounds,
  • real-world debugging scenarios.

You will reuse this framework for every problem in this section.

item.title: Problem Solving Strategy for Coding Interviews — A Phase-Based Learning Approach
item.description:
Problem Solving — A Phase-Based Learning Strategy

After understanding how interviews evaluate problem solving
and how to approach an individual problem, the next question is:

How should I structure my overall preparation so it actually works?

This article answers that.

1. Why a Phase-Based Strategy Is Necessary

Most interview preparation fails for one reason:

People mix learning, speed, and interview pressure together.

This creates:

  • panic under time pressure
  • shallow pattern recognition
  • fragile solutions

To avoid this, problem solving must be learned in distinct phases, each with a clear goal.
